definitions: flat triangular bone protecting the knee joint from injury
act of shooting someone in the knee as punishment or intimidation
examples: The doctor examined her swollen kneecap after the fall
Football players often wear padding to protect their kneecaps
The crime syndicate threatened to kneecap anyone who betrayed them
Kneecapping was a common punishment during the conflict

definitions: act of lowering oneself to rest on one or both knees
examples: The knight had to kneel before receiving his honor
People often kneel during prayer in many religious traditions

definitions: position or state of being on one or both knees
examples: The gardener spent hours kneeling while planting the flowers
Kneeling during the ceremony showed respect to the elders

definitions: solemn sound of a bell rung slowly for a death or funeral
signal or warning of the end or failure of something
examples: The church bell's knell echoed through the village at noon
They could hear the funeral knell from miles away
The bankruptcy sounded the death knell for the company
Critics saw it as the knell of traditional journalism

definitions: sharp-bladed instrument with a handle used for cutting or spreading
bladed weapon used for attack or defense in combat situations
examples: She used a sharp knife to slice the vegetables precisely
The chef sharpened his favorite knife before starting dinner
The suspect was arrested for carrying a concealed knife
Ancient warriors often carried knives as backup weapons

definitions: mounted warrior in armor serving a feudal lord in medieval times
chess piece that moves in an L-shaped pattern on the board
person awarded an honorary title by a monarch for distinguished service
examples: The knight rode into battle wearing shining armor
Medieval knights followed a strict code of chivalry
She moved her knight to threaten the opponent's queen
The knight is worth about three pawns in chess
Sir Paul McCartney was made a knight by Queen Elizabeth
The scientist became a knight for his medical discoveries

definitions: rank or dignity of being a knight conferred as an honor
system and practices of medieval knights including their code of conduct
examples: The actor received a knighthood for his contributions to drama
Her knighthood ceremony took place at Buckingham Palace
The museum exhibit explored knighthood in medieval Europe
Knighthood required years of training from childhood

definitions: fabric or garment made by interlocking loops of yarn with needles
examples: She wore a beautiful hand knit sweater to the party
The store specializes in luxury knit clothing from Italy

definitions: craft of creating fabric by interlocking loops of yarn with needles
piece of knitted work in progress or completed knitted items
examples: Her grandmother taught her knitting when she was young
Knitting has become a popular stress-relief hobby recently
She brought her knitting to work on during the flight
The basket held various pieces of unfinished knitting

definitions: clothing made from knitted fabric including sweaters, cardigans, and similar garments
examples: The boutique specializes in luxury Italian knitwear
She invested in quality knitwear for the winter season

definitions: rounded handle on a door or drawer for opening
rotating control on a device for adjusting settings
rounded lump or protrusion on a surface
examples: She turned the brass knob to enter the room
The antique dresser had ornate crystal knobs
He adjusted the volume knob on the radio
The stove has knobs for controlling each burner
The walking stick had decorative knobs along its length
Tree knobs can be used for climbing

definitions: sharp sound made by striking a hard surface
critical or disparaging comment about someone or something
setback or misfortune that causes difficulty or damage
examples: There was a loud knock at the door
The engine made a worrying knock when starting
The movie received several knocks from harsh critics
That unfair knock on his reputation still bothers him
The business took a knock during the recession
Her confidence suffered a knock after the rejection

definitions: act of knocking someone down especially in boxing or fighting
substantial reduction in price or cost
furniture designed to be easily assembled and disassembled
examples: The boxer scored a knockdown in the third round
It was his fifth knockdown of the championship season
The store offered knockdown prices during the clearance sale
They got the car at a knockdown price
The knockdown furniture was perfect for their temporary apartment
Assembly of the knockdown bookshelf took only minutes

definitions: continuous or repeated sound of striking against a surface
examples: The persistent knocking on the door woke everyone up
Strange knocking sounds came from inside the walls

definitions: victory in boxing when an opponent cannot continue fighting
exceptionally attractive or impressive person or thing
competition stage where losing means elimination from the tournament
examples: The heavyweight champion won by knockout in round seven
It was the fastest knockout in boxing history
She looked like an absolute knockout in that dress
The new sports car is a real knockout
They advanced through the knockout stages to the final
The knockout round determines who reaches the semifinals

definitions: small rounded hill or mound rising from surrounding land
examples: They had a picnic on the grassy knoll overlooking the valley
The house sat atop a gentle knoll surrounded by trees

definitions: fastening made by tying rope, string, or fabric together
nautical unit of speed equal to one nautical mile per hour
hard lump in wood where a branch grew
tight area of muscle tissue causing pain or discomfort
examples: She tied a secure knot to hold the boat
The scout learned to tie twelve different knots
The ship was traveling at twenty knots
Wind speed reached forty knots during the storm
The carpenter worked around the knots in the pine board
Wood with many knots is often less expensive
The massage therapist worked out the knots in her shoulders
Stress often causes knots to form in neck muscles

definitions: state of having knowledge or being aware of something
examples: His knowing of the situation gave him an advantage
There was a certain knowing between the old friends

definitions: facts, information, and skills acquired through experience or education
theoretical or practical understanding of a subject or situation
specialized information or expertise in a particular domain or field
examples: Her knowledge of history impressed the entire class
The test will assess your knowledge of basic mathematics
His deep knowledge of human nature made him a great writer
True knowledge comes from questioning and exploration
She has extensive knowledge in artificial intelligence research
Medical knowledge has advanced dramatically this century

definitions: bony joint of a finger, especially when clenched in a fist
cut of meat from the knee joint of an animal
examples: He cracked his knuckles before starting to type
The fighter's knuckles were bruised after the match
The butcher recommended pork knuckle for the soup
Roasted lamb knuckle is a traditional holiday dish

definitions: tree-dwelling Australian marsupial with gray fur that feeds exclusively on eucalyptus leaves
examples: The koala spent most of the day sleeping in the tree
Australia's koala population faces threats from habitat loss

definitions: person regarded as strange, eccentric, or crazy in their behavior
examples: Everyone thought he was a kook for his unusual inventions
The beach attracts all kinds of kooks and characters

definitions: food prepared according to Jewish religious dietary requirements and regulations
examples: The restaurant serves only kosher meals to its customers
They keep a strictly kosher kitchen at home

definitions: strong brown paper made from chemically treated wood pulp
examples: She wrapped the package in sturdy kraft paper
The grocery store uses kraft paper bags

definitions: fortified complex in Russian cities, especially the one in Moscow
seat of Russian government and metonym for Russian political leadership
examples: Tourists visited the historic kremlin with its ancient walls
The Moscow Kremlin houses several cathedrals and palaces
The Kremlin issued a statement about the international situation
Diplomats awaited the Kremlin's response to sanctions

definitions: small shrimp-like marine crustaceans that form the primary food for whales
examples: Whales can consume tons of krill in a single feeding
Antarctic krill populations support the entire marine ecosystem

definitions: colorless, odorless noble gas element used in fluorescent lights and lasers
examples: Krypton gas fills some types of light bulbs
Scientists use krypton lasers for precise measurements

definitions: room or building equipped for scientific research, experiments, or teaching
examples: The scientists worked late in the lab every night
Students conduct chemistry experiments in the school lab

definitions: piece of material attached to an object giving information about it
company brand under which music, fashion, or products are marketed
classifying name or phrase applied to a person or group
examples: She checked the label for washing instructions
The jar needs a label showing its contents
The band signed with a major record label
Designer labels often command premium prices
Society often puts labels on people unfairly
The label 'millennial' encompasses a diverse generation

definitions: physical or mental work, especially of a difficult or exhausting nature
workers collectively, especially those doing manual or industrial work
process of childbirth from contractions to delivery of a baby
examples: The construction required months of hard labor
Manual labor built the railroad across the country
The company negotiated with labor representatives for better wages
Labor unions protect workers' rights and interests
She went into labor at three in the morning
The labor lasted twelve hours before delivery

definitions: room or building equipped with apparatus for scientific experiments, research, or teaching
examples: The medical laboratory analyzed blood samples from patients
University laboratories provide hands-on learning for science students

definitions: person doing physical work for wages, especially outdoor or construction work
examples: Farm laborers harvested the crops before the storm
Construction laborers worked through the summer heat

definitions: physical or mental work, especially of a difficult or exhausting nature
workers collectively, especially those doing manual or industrial work
process of childbirth from contractions to delivery of a baby
examples: The project required intensive labour over many months
Agricultural labour was essential to the economy
Labour protests led to improved working conditions
The Labour Party represents workers' interests
The midwife assisted during the difficult labour
Labour pains began early in the evening

definitions: person doing physical work for wages, especially outdoor or construction work
examples: Railway labourers built the transcontinental railroad
Seasonal labourers help with the harvest each year

definitions: complicated network of paths or passages difficult to navigate
complex system of fluid-filled channels in the inner ear controlling balance
examples: The garden featured a beautiful hedge labyrinth
They got lost in the labyrinth of underground tunnels
Damage to the labyrinth can cause severe dizziness
The doctor examined her inner ear labyrinth

definitions: delicate fabric made of yarn or thread in an open weblike pattern
cord or string used to fasten shoes or clothing by threading through holes
examples: Her wedding dress featured intricate handmade lace
The curtains were trimmed with delicate Belgian lace
He replaced the broken laces in his running shoes
The corset fastened with silk laces up the back

definitions: system of cords or strings threaded through holes for fastening
decorative trimming or edging made with lace or similar material
examples: The boot's lacing system provided excellent ankle support
Traditional corsets used complex lacing patterns
Gold lacing adorned the military uniform
The dress featured beautiful lacing along the sleeves

definitions: state of being without or not having enough of something
deficiency or shortage of something needed or desired
examples: The lack of rain caused severe drought conditions
His lack of experience showed in the interview
There's a serious lack of affordable housing in the city
The project failed due to lack of funding

definitions: person who behaves obsequiously to those in power or authority
uniformed manservant or footman in a wealthy household
examples: The corrupt official surrounded himself with loyal lackeys
Critics dismissed them as corporate lackeys
The mansion employed several lackeys in formal livery
Historical dramas often feature lackeys serving nobility

definitions: hard glossy coating applied to wood or metal for protection
decorative varnish often used in Asian art and furniture
examples: The table received three coats of clear lacquer
Nail lacquer protects and beautifies fingernails
The Japanese lacquer box was a valuable antique
Red lacquer furniture adorned the Chinese restaurant

definitions: team sport played with long-handled sticks with nets for catching and throwing a ball
examples: She played lacrosse throughout high school and college
Native Americans invented the game of lacrosse centuries ago

definitions: natural sugar found in milk and dairy products that some people cannot digest
examples: Many adults develop lactose intolerance as they age
The label indicated the product contained lactose

definitions: boy or young man, often used informally or affectionately
examples: The local lads played football in the park
He was just a young lad when he started working

definitions: portable structure with rungs for climbing up or down
hierarchical system of progression in career or organization
vertical run in stockings or tights caused by broken threads
examples: He climbed the ladder to reach the roof
The fire department arrived with their tall ladders
She quickly climbed the corporate ladder to success
The career ladder in banking is highly competitive
She noticed a ladder in her stockings during the meeting
One snag created a ladder running up her tights

definitions: large long-handled spoon with a deep bowl for serving liquids
examples: She used a ladle to serve soup into bowls
The punch bowl came with a decorative silver ladle

definitions: adult female person, especially one of refinement or high social position
polite or formal way of referring to a woman
woman of noble rank or the wife of a lord or knight
examples: The lady at the reception desk was very helpful
Several ladies attended the charity luncheon
Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to tonight's performance
The lady of the house greeted us warmly
Lady Diana became a beloved public figure
The lady of the manor hosted elaborate parties

definitions: small round beetle with bright red or yellow wing covers marked with spots
examples: Children love finding ladybirds in the garden
Ladybirds help control aphid populations naturally

definitions: small round beetle with bright red or yellow wing covers marked with spots
examples: The ladybug landed gently on her finger
Farmers welcome ladybugs as natural pest controllers

definitions: period of time between one event and another related event
material used to insulate pipes, boilers, or other equipment
examples: There's always a lag between policy changes and results
The video conference suffered from annoying audio lag
They installed pipe lag to prevent freezing in winter
Proper lag reduces heat loss from hot water pipes

definitions: light-colored beer fermented at low temperatures and stored before drinking
examples: He ordered a cold lager after work
German lagers are famous for their crisp taste
